titleStmt.title: Admonitions by the Supreame Councell of the Confederat Catholicks of Ireand [sic] to all His Majesties faithfull loyall subjects of the three Kingdomes of England, Ireland, and Scotland against a Solemn League and Covenant framed by the malignant partie in the Parliament of England : as also against a declaration of the English Lords and Commons assembled in Parliament.

notesStmt.note: A Solemne League and Covenant for reformation and defence of religion. London: Printed for Edward Husbands, Octob. 9, 1643 (p. [7]-12) and A declaration of the Lords and Commons assembled in Parliament shewing the present design now on foot ... for a cessation of armes ... London: Printed for Io. VVright ... Octob. 2, 1645 (p. [15-22]) have special title pages.
Reproduction of original in Cambridge University Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: ADMONITIONS BY THE SVPREAME COVNCELL OF THE CONFEDERAT CATHOLICKS OF IREAND, To all his Maje≈øties faithfull Loyall Subjects of the three Kingdomes of England, Ireland, and Scotland.
Again≈øt a Solemne League and Covenant framed by the malignant partie in the Parliament of England.

p.hi: As al≈øo again≈øt a Declaration of the English Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament.

div.p:
Printed by Command of the ≈øaid Supreame Councell, „Äà‚óä„Äâ
VVaterford by Thomas Bourke, 26. Ian. 1643.

div.head: BY THE SVPREAME COVNCELL OF THE CONFEDERAT CATHOLICKS of IRELAND.
div.p:
HAving ≈øince the la≈øt generall A≈ø≈øembly of the ≈øaid Confederat Catholicks held at the City of VVaterford ≈øeene a Solemne league and Covenant, framed by the Malignant party in the Parliament of England, and by them procured to be ≈øworne by ≈øuch of his Maje≈øties Subjects as they could ≈øeduce in the kingdome of England, and Scotland, and ≈øent likewi≈øe into ≈øome parts of this kingdome, to infect others, wherein are contained re≈øolutions ≈øo de≈øtructive to the Profe≈ø≈øors of the Catholicke Faith in generall, to his Maje≈øties Prote≈øtant Subjects and this Nation in particular, that wee ≈øhould betray the tru≈øt repo≈øed in us, had wee not given timely notice thereof to the ≈øaid Confederat Catholicks, whereby they may bee forewarned of their utter extirpation intended, ≈øo farre as may lie in the power of the ≈øaid Malignant party, to which end we have cau≈øed the ≈øaid ≈øolemne league & Covenant to be printed, in which all Chri≈øtian Princes and their good Subjects may ob≈øerve, the in≈øolency of the ≈øaid rebellious incendiaries being not ≈øatisfied to have withdrawne them≈øelves from their allegeance, and to have rai≈øed armes again≈øt ≈øo gracious a King, but al≈øo thereby endeavour to poy≈øon the mindes of the faithfull Subjects of other Princes with their di≈øloyalty, in≈øerting in the preamble of that Rebellious Covenant the≈øe words (calling to minde the treacherous and bloudy plotts, Con≈øpiracies, attempts, and practi≈øes of the enemies of God against the true Religion and profe≈ø≈øors thereof in all places) not confining them≈øelves to the three kingdomes of England, Ireland, and Scotland, And in the perclo≈øe of that Covenant, adding the≈øe words (mo≈øt humbly
be≈øeeching the Lord to ≈øtrengthen us by his Holy Spirit, for this end and to ble≈ø≈øe our de≈øignes and proceedings with ≈øuch ≈øucce≈ø≈øe as may be deliverance and ≈øafety to his people, and encouragement to other Chri≈øtian Churches groaning under, or in danger of the yoake of Antichri≈øtian tyranny to joyne in the ≈øame or the like a≈ø≈øociation and Covenant.) By which all the world may evidently ≈øee; how far they de≈øire their trea≈øon again≈øt Monarchie to be ≈øpred, by ≈øuch and the like Covenant and malicious practi≈øe, and in other the partes of that oath, bounded to the limitts of the three Kingdomes of England, Ireland, and Scotland, they ≈øweare to a reformation (as they tearme it) of Religion in England, and Ireland, and to endeavour to bring the Church of God in the ≈øaid three kingdomes to uniformitie in Religion and Confe≈øsion of Faith, and that they shall in like manner without re≈øpect of per≈øons endeavour the extirpation of Popery and Prelacy, as hereafter in the oath is more at large expre≈ø≈øed, whereby the Catholicks of England, Ireland, and Scotland may plainely for≈øee what rigour they are to expect, and how they ≈øtand forewarned to prepare them≈øelves for a defen≈øive and offen≈øive warre again≈øt the ≈øaid Malignant party, or failing therein will be driven to quit all they can call theirs in England, Ireland, and Scotland. How vaine it is for any his Maje≈øties Catholicke Subjects to hope for mercy, at the hands of that party, when the generall words (without re≈øpect of per≈øons,) have left no exemption for any, but would extirpate all without di≈øtinction of per≈øon, or difference of quality, contrary to the law of Nations, and when their malice is ≈øo high ≈øwolne that they a≈ø≈øume Regall authoritie ≈øo farre as to pre≈øume to proclaime warre again≈øt us, their fellow Subjects, even in the be≈øt times of their loyaltie, and that without any relation to his Maje≈øties allowance. So as wee are to expect no peace untill they bee reclaimed, and when they ≈øo de≈øpi≈øe the power and intere≈øt of his Maje≈øtie, and of his Prote≈øtant and Catholicke Subjects of the three kingdomes, as that they re≈øolve likewi≈øe the extirpation of Archbishops, Bishops, Prelats & all other dignitaries of what religion ≈øoever, we therefore being bound by the oath of a≈ø≈øociation ≈øolemnely by us taken to pre≈øerve our Religion, maintaine the priviledges and ju≈øt prerogatives of our Sacred Soveraigne, and defend the liberties of our Countrey, ob≈øerving by the ≈øini≈øter and un godly practi≈øes of the ≈øaid Malignant
party that the whole ≈øcope of their wicked intentions is to extirpate the Catholicke Religion, and the profe≈ø≈øors thereof in the ≈øaid three kingdomes, de≈øtroy Monarchie, deprive our ≈øaid Soveraigne of his ju≈øt prerogatives, and bani≈øh or put to death all ≈øuch of his Maje≈øties Subjects, a≈øwell Protestants, as Catholicks who will not conforme them≈øelves to their doctrine, ≈øo erronious and de≈øtructive to the rights of Monarchie, in di≈øcharge of our ≈øaid oath, for the pre≈øervation of our Religion, in ob≈øervance of our Loyalty to our ≈øaid Sacred Soveraigne, the maintenance of his Prerogatives, the defence of our lives, liberties and e≈øtates, and lives liberties & e≈øtates of all his Maje≈øties well affected Subjects in his ≈øaid three Kingdomes, doe earne≈øtly de≈øire them upon view & peru≈øall of the ≈øaid Covenant ≈øeriou≈øly to con≈øider the dangerous and foule intentions of the ≈øaid evill projectors, & to make full & timely preparation for the ≈øafety of them≈øelves and their po≈øteritie, and doe al≈øo de≈øire all Catholicke Princes & their good Subjects, a≈ø≈øecting the pre≈øervation of their Religion, & the Rights of Soveraignty, to con≈øider how far they are concerned in that ≈øo bloudy & impious a re≈øolution, & to find a timely & fit remedy to be applied to ≈øo contagious a de≈øigne, which the ≈øaid Malignant party would invite the Subjects of all Christian Princes to intertaine.
A SOLEMNE LEAGVE AND COVENANT FOR REFORMATION AND DEFENCE OF RELIGION The honour and happine≈ø≈øe of the KING, and the peace and ≈øafety of the three Kingdomes, of England, Scotland, and Ireland.
Al≈øo two ≈øpeciall orders viz.
1 Concerning the taking of the League and Covenant in all Churches and Chappells in London and VVestmin≈øter, upon the next Lords day in the afternoone.

2. Concerning divers L√≤rds, Knights, Gentlemen, Colonells, Officers, Souldiours, and others, that are de≈øirous to meet this pre≈øent Friday in the afternoone at Margarets VVe≈øtminster, and to take the ≈øaid League and Covenant.

q.p: Ier. 50.5. Come let us ioyne our ≈øelves to the Lord in a perpetuall Covenant, that ≈øhall not be forgotten.
Prov. 25.5. Take away the wicked from before the King, and his Throne ≈øhall be e≈øtabli≈øhed in righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe.

2 Chro. 15.15. And all Iudah reioyced at the Oath, for they had ≈øworne with all their heart, and ≈øought him with their whole de≈øire, and he was found of them, and the Lord gave them re≈øt round about.

body.p: It is this day ordered by the Commons in Parliament. That this Covenant and Orders bee forthwith printed and publi≈øhed,

closer.signed: H. El≈øings Cl. Parl. D. Com.

div.p: London, Printed for Edward Husbands, Octob. 9. 1643.

div.head: Die Lunae 25. Septemb. 1643.
div.p: IT is this day ordered by the Commons now a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, that the Mini≈øters in all the Parish Churches and Chappells of London, VVe≈øtmin≈øter, Suburbs and Liberties, and in all Pari≈øhes within the Bills of Mortality, doe read the ≈øolemne League and Covenant on Wedne≈øday next, being the day of publicke humiliation; And doe explane it, and urge the ground and nece≈ø≈øity of it, and exhort the people to the cheerfull taking of it, and that the ≈øeverall Inhabitants and Pari≈øhioners of the ≈øeverall and re≈øpective Pari≈øhes arfore≈øaid, and Students of the Innes of Court doe take the ≈øaid League and Covenant on the Lords day next in the afternoone: And that notice hereof be given to my Lord Mayor, and his Lord≈øhip de≈øired to give timely notice hereof to the places afore≈øaid. The Mini≈øters are likewi≈øe to give notice, that the Comi≈ø≈øioners of Scotland now here doe take it here.

closer.signed: Hen. El≈øinge. Cler. Parl. D. Cem.

div.head: Die Sabbathi, 30. Sept. 1643.
div.p: WHereas divers Lords, Knights, Gentlemen and divers Colonells, Officers and Souldiours, and others now re≈øiding in the Cities of London and VVe≈øtminster and within the line of Communication, are de≈øirous to meere at Saint Margarets Church at VVestminster on Friday next, to take the ≈øolemne League and Covenant for Reformation, and defence of the honour and happine≈ø≈øe of the King, and the peace and ≈øafety of the three Kingdomes, of England, Scotland and Ireland. And whereas divers of the Scottish Nation, are de≈øirous likewi≈øe to meet at the ≈øame time and place and divers Mini≈øters who have no charge within the ≈øaid limits to take the ≈øaid Covenant.

It is this day ordered by the Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament; That M. Carrill of Lincolus Inne be de≈øired to preach on Friday next in the forenoone, to tho≈øe that ≈øhall ≈øo meet, for the taking of the ≈øaid Covenant; And a Parchment Rolle with the ≈øaid Covenant written therein, ≈øhall be prepared for every one that take the ≈øaid Covenant to ≈øub≈øcribe his name and Colonell Long and M. Iohn Browne members of the ≈øaid Hou≈øe, are to ≈øee the names ≈øub≈øcribed accordingly: And this order is appointed to be printed and publi≈øhed forthwith.

closer.signed: Hen. El≈øinge Cler. Parl. D. Com.

div.head: A ≈øolemne League and Covenant for Reformation and defence of Religion, the honour and happine≈ø≈øe of the King, and the peace and ≈øafety of the three Kingdomes of England, Scotland, and Ireland.
div.p: WE Noblemen, Barons, Knights, Gentlemen, Citizens, Burge≈ø≈øes, Mini≈øters of the Go≈øpell, and Commons of all ≈øorts in the Kingdomes of England, Scotland and Ireland, by the providence of God living under one King, and being of one reformed religion, having before our eyes the glory of God, and the advancement of the Kingdome of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, the honour and happine≈ø≈øe of the Kings Maje≈øtie and his po≈øterity, and the true publicke liberty, ≈øafety and peace of the kingdomes, wherein every ones private condition is included, and calling to mind the treacherous and bloudy plotts, con≈øpiracies, attempts, and practi≈øes of the enemies of God again≈øt the true Religion, and profe≈ø≈øors thereof in all places, e≈øpecially in the≈øe three kingdomes, ever ≈øince the reformation of Religion, and how much their rage, power and pre≈øumption, are of late, and at this time increa≈øed and exerci≈øed, whereof the deplorable ≈øtate of the Church and Kingdome of Ireland, the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed e≈øtate of the Church and kingdome of England, and the dangerous e≈øtate of the Church and kingdome of Scotland, are pre≈øent and publicke te≈øtimonies. We have now at la≈øt after other meanes of ≈øupplication, remon≈øtrance, Prote≈øtations and ≈øufferings, for the pre≈øervation of our ≈øelves and our Religion, from utter ruine and de≈øtruction, according to the commendable practi≈øe of the≈øe kingdomes in former times, and the example of Gods people in other Nations; after mature deliberation, re≈øolved and determined to enter into a mutuall and ≈øolemne League and Covenant, wherein we all ≈øub≈øcribe, & each one of us for him≈øelfe, with our hands lifted up to the mo≈øt High God, doe ≈øweare.

1. That we ≈øhall ≈øincerely, really, and con≈øtantly through the grace of God, endeavour in our ≈øeverall places and callings, the pre≈øervation of the reformed Religion in the Church of Scotland, in doctrine wor≈øhip, di≈øcipline and government, again≈øt our
common enemyes, the reformation of Religion in the kingdomes of England and Ireland, in doctrine, wor≈øhip, di≈øcipline, and governement, according to the Word of God, and the example of the be≈øt reformed Churches. And ≈øhall endeavour to bring the Churches of God in the three kingdomes to the neere≈øt conjunction and uniformity in religion, confe≈ø≈øion of Faith, Forme of Church governement, directory for wor≈øhip, and Cathechi≈øing, that wee and all our po≈øterity after us, may as brethren live in Faith and love, and the Lord may delight to dwell in the midde≈øt of us.

2. That we ≈øhall in the like manner without re≈øpect of per≈øons, endeavour the extirpation of Popery, Prelacy, that is, Church-governement, by Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, their Chauncellours and Commi≈ø≈øaries, Deanes, Chapters, Archdeacons, and all other Eccle≈øia≈øticall officers depending on that Hierarchie, ≈øuper≈øtition, here≈øie, ≈øchi≈øme, prophanene≈ø≈øe, and what≈øoever ≈øhall be found to be contrary to ≈øound doctrine, and the power of godline≈ø≈øe, le≈øt we partake in other mens ≈øinnes, and thereby be in danger to receive of their plagues, and that the Lord may bee one, and his Name one in the three kingdomes.

3. We ≈øhall with the ≈øame ≈øincerity, reallity, and con≈øtancy in our ≈øeverall vocations, endeavour with our e≈øtates and lives, mutually to pre≈øerve the rights and priviledges of Parliaments, and the liberties of the kingdomes; and to pre≈øerve and defend the Kings Maje≈øties per≈øon and authority in the pre≈øervation and defence of the true Religion and Liberties of the kingdomes, that the world may beare witne≈ø≈øe with our con≈øciences of our Loyaltie, and that we have no thoughts or intentions to dimini≈øh his Maje≈øties ju≈øt power and greatne≈ø≈øe.

4. Wee ≈øhall al≈øo with all faithfulne≈ø≈øe endeavour the di≈øcovery of all ≈øuch as have beene, or ≈øhall be incendiaties, malignants or evill in≈øtruments, by hindering the reformation of Religion, dividing the King from his people, or one of the kingdomes from another, or making any faction or parties among≈øt the people, contrary to this League and Covenant, that they may be brought to publicke triall, and receive coÃÑndigne puni≈øhment, as the degree of their offences ≈øhall require or de≈øerve, or the ≈øupreame Iudicatories of both kingdomes re≈øpectively, or others having power from them for that effect, ≈øhall judge convenient.

5. And whereas the happine≈ø≈øe of a ble≈ø≈øed peace betweene the≈øe kingdomes, denyed in former times to our progenitors, is by the good providence of God granted unto us, and hath beene lately concluded, and ≈øetled by both Parliaments, we ≈øhall each of us according to our place and intere≈øt endeavour that they may remaine conjoyned in a firme peace, and union to all po≈øterity: And that Iu≈øtice may be done upon the wilfull oppo≈øers thereof, in manner expre≈ø≈øed in the precedent Article.

6. We ≈øhall al≈øo according to our places and callings in this common cau≈øe of Religion, liberty and peace of the kingdomes, a≈ø≈øi≈øt and defend all tho≈øe that enter into this League, and Covenant, in the maintaining and pur≈øuing thereof, and ≈øhall not ≈øuffer our ≈øelves directly nor indirectly by who≈øoever combination, per≈øwa≈øion or terrour, to be divided from this ble≈ø≈øed union and conjunction, whether to make defection to the contrary parts or to give our ≈øelves to a dete≈øtable indifferency or neutrality in this cau≈øe, which ≈øo much concerneth the glory of God, the good of the kingdomes, and honour of the King, but ≈øhall all the dayes of our lives zealou≈øly and con≈øtantly continue therein, again≈øt all oppo≈øition, and promote the ≈øame according to our power again≈øt all letts and impediments what≈øoever; and what wee are not able our≈øelves to ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe or overcome, wee ≈øhall reveale and make knowne that it may be timely prevented, all which, wee ≈øhall doe as in the ≈øight of God.

And becau≈øe the≈øe kingdomes are guilty of many ≈øins and provocations again≈øt God, and his Sonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, as is too manife≈øt, by our pre≈øent di≈øtre≈ø≈øes and dangers, the fruits thereof; we profe≈ø≈øe and declare before God, and the world, our unfayned de≈øire to bee humbled for our owne ≈øins, and for the ≈øins of the≈øe kingdomes, e≈øpecially, that wee have not as wee ought valued the ine≈øtimable benefit of the Go≈øpell, that wee have not laboured for the purity and power thereof, and that wee have not endeavoured to receive Chri≈øt in our hearts, nor to walke worthy of him in our lives, which are the cau≈øes of other ≈øins and tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions ≈øo much abounding among≈øt us; And our true and unfained purpo≈øe, de≈øire, and endeavour for our ≈øelves, and all others under our power and charge, both in publicke and in private, in all duties we owe to God and man, to amend our lives,
and each one to goe before other in the example of a reall Reformation, that the Lord may turne away his wrath and heavy indignation, and e≈øtabli≈øh the≈øe Churches and kingdomes in truth and peace, and this Covenant wee make in the pre≈øence of Almighty God, the ≈øearcher of all hearts, with a true intention to performe the ≈øame as we ≈øhall an≈øwer at that great day, when the ≈øecrets of all hearts ≈øhall bee di≈øclo≈øed; mo≈øt humbly be≈øeeching the Lord to ≈øtrengthen us by his Holy Spirit for this end, and to ble≈ø≈øe our de≈øires and proceedings, with ≈øuch ≈øucce≈ø≈øe as may bee deliverance and ≈øafety to his people, and encouragement to other Chri≈øtian Churches, groaning under, or in danger of the yoake of Antichri≈øtian Tyranny, to joyne in the ≈øame, or like A≈ø≈øociation and Covenant, to the glory of God, the enlargement of the Kingdome of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, and the peace and tranquillity of Chri≈øtian Kingdomes and Commonwealths.

div.head: BY THE SVPREAME COVNCELL OF THE CONFEDERAT CATHOLICKS of IRELAND.
div.p:
THe en≈øueing Declaration having come to our hands ≈øoone after the rece≈ø≈øe of the late Generall A≈ø≈øembly of the Confederate Catholicks held at VVaterford, wee thought fit for the better publi≈øhing thereof, in all the parts of this kingdome, that the ≈øame ≈øhould bee printed, whereby his Maje≈øties good Subjects, may evidently ≈øee, what in≈øolent expre≈ø≈øions are therein contained, again≈øt his Maje≈øties power, and proceedings, again≈øt his Maje≈øties Catholicke Subjects, & again≈øt all well minded Prote≈øtants, that labour to ≈øettle a right under≈øtanding, betwixt his Maje≈øtie & his Subjects of this kingdome: they take upon them to Cen≈øure his Maje≈øty for di≈øplacing per≈øons affected to Religion, and putting into their places men Popishly addicted, or in plaine English for di≈øplacing Sir VVilliam Par≈øons, and appointing Sir Henry Tichborne one of the Iu≈øtices, and of the re≈øt it is apparant whom they meane, they take notice that in his Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øion ≈øent hither to receive the Grievances of his people, ≈øome of the Commi≈ø≈øioners were Papi≈øts, there being none named of ≈øuch as they intend thereby, but the Earle of Clanrikard, (whom it ≈øeemeth they thinke) either unworthy of that honour, or unfit to be tru≈øted: they ≈øay, that the Catholicks of this kingdome are reduced to ≈øuch Nece≈ø≈øity, that they devoure and eate one another, which (prai≈øe be to God) is mo≈øt fal≈øe, our markets being in mo≈øt places, as well ≈øupplied as at any time before: and where tho≈øe here of the State, that did adhere, to the malignant party in England, re≈øolved to de≈øtroy this Nation by famine, and to that purpo≈øe advi≈øed all the Cornes, in the
march of the forces, to bee burned, and accordingly very much Corne was Burned, many thou≈øands of the ≈øaid forces by the ju≈øt Iudgment of God peri≈øhed within their Garri≈øons in ≈øundry parts of this kingdome for want of victualls, they laboured to hinder any Ce≈ø≈øation with the ≈øaid Catholicks, urging that the de≈øigne thereof did ari≈øe fir≈øt from them, (an objection proper to ≈øuch as rebell again≈øt their King,) ought not a dutifull people to petition for redre≈ø≈øe of their grievances to their Prince, they affirme that the rai≈øing of Armes by this Nation, (which they Call Rebellion,) was without provocation, but re≈øolutions of extirpating, the Catholicke Religion, and the profe≈ø≈øors thereof, in this kingdome, will be proved, not onely by te≈øtimony of Catholicks, but even of many Prote≈øtants, and then all the world they hope will witne≈ø≈øe with them the ju≈øtne≈ø≈øe, and nece≈ø≈øity of this war: and though they in≈øult of ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, and in≈øinuate, that the Catholicks failing to prevaile by ≈øtrength, have recour≈øe to Craft. Yet it is well knowne that in mo≈øt Conflicts the lo≈ø≈øe was greater of the other ≈øide: the Authors of this Declaration are not ≈øatisfied to have overbu≈øied them≈øelves and a≈ø≈øumed Regall Power in England, but hereby let the Coun≈øell of State here, know, how highly they have offended, that they acquainted them not with the intention of a Ce≈ø≈øation of Armes, and let them al≈øo know, that they repre≈øented the wants of the Armies here unto the Parliament of England, with much Craft to have a ground, wherewith to collour the Ce≈ø≈øation as if his Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øion were not ≈øufficient to ju≈øtifie their proceedings therein, and conclude with this inference, that the forces here by meanes of this Ce≈ø≈øation, will find opportunity to joyne with the Popish party in England, for their greater ≈øtrengthning, by all which it is evident, that if the u≈øurped Regall power of tho≈øe incendiaries, can have influence on Ireland, that none with, or without his Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øion ≈øhall ≈øtand ju≈øtified, but ≈øuch as adhere to them and their Rebellion, and for≈øake their Loyalty, and obedience to his Maje≈øties Commands.
A DECLARATION OF THE LORDS AND COMMONS ASSEMBLED IN PARLIAMENT.

Shewing the pre≈øent de≈øigne now on foot (by vertue of a pretended Comi≈ø≈øion from his Maje≈øtie) for a ce≈ø≈øation of Armes, or treaty of peace with the Rebells in Ireland, now they are brought to ≈øuch a low condition, that they are inforced to devoure and eate one another, in ≈øome parts of that kingdome: And by what Popi≈øh in≈øtruments and mini≈øters in their Councell at the Court, the ≈øaid de≈øigne is, and hath been carried on, per≈øons of great tru≈øt, eminent for their affection or Religion and hatred of the Rebells being di≈øplaced, and men Popi≈øhly addicted put in their offices: all ≈øerving for the better introduction of Popery, and extirpation of the true Prote≈øtant Religion in that and other of his Maje≈øties dominions.

p.hi: Ordered by the Lords and Commons a≈øsembled in Parliament that this declaration shall be forthwith printed and published.

div.p: London, Printed for Io. VVright in old Baily, Octob. 2. 1645.

div.head: A DECLARATION OF THE LORDS AND COMMONS ASSEMBLED IN PARLIAMENT,
div.p:
AS it is evident to all the world that this late horrid Rebellion of the Papi≈øts in Ireland did without any colour or pretext of provocation profe≈ø≈øedly and boldly ayme at the de≈øtruction of the Protestant Religion, the rejecting of the lawes of England, and the extirpation of the Brittish inhabitants out of that kingdome; ≈øo it is no le≈ø≈øe manife≈øt that this Parliament of England (to whom his Maje≈øty hath left the managing of the warre again≈øt tho≈øe rebels) hath taken the troubles of Ireland to heart with that re≈øentment and compa≈ø≈øion as may evidence their zeale to Religion, their love to their di≈øtre≈øt Countreymen and brethren there, in the≈øe times, when the Ie≈øuiticall practi≈øes have ca≈øt England into wofull di≈øtractions, and unnaturall warre, notwith≈øtanding
which, the reducing of Ireland hath ≈øtill beene a chiefe part of the care of this Parliament, And God hath beene plea≈øed to ble≈ø≈øe our endeavours with ≈øuch ≈øucce≈ø≈øe as that tho≈øe furious bloud, thir≈øty Papi≈øts have beene in the carrier of their crueltie, ≈øome part of the Protestant bloud which at fir≈øt was ≈øpilt like water upon the ground hath beene revenged, their ma≈ø≈øacres, burnings and fami≈øhings, have by a divine retaliation beene repayde into their bo≈øome; And the Prote≈øtant party hath been erected to that condition of ≈øtrenght and hope, that their enemies are con≈øtrayned (di≈øtru≈øting their forces) to have recour≈øe to their craft & policies, and therefore by their ≈øubtill Agents at Court, and their active in≈øtruments el≈øewhere, have beene endeavoring now of along time to make our Armies in Ireland di≈øaffected to the Parliament, what by occa≈øion of their wants not ≈øo readily ≈øupplyed as their neede required, what by mi≈øu≈øing them with the≈øe unhappy differences fallen in here betweene King & People, labouring by that meanes to devide tho≈øe forces into factions, to the end the maine worke they have in hand might be neglected, which is the pro≈øecution of the warre again≈øt the Rebels, & ≈øo far brought low in ≈øome partes of Ireland, that if they can bee deprived of the benefit of this Harve≈øt, they are not likely to ≈øee the next Summer. And therefore the Rebels finding that notwith≈øtanding the di≈øtractions here occa≈øioning the ≈ølowne≈ø≈øe & ≈øcarcene≈ø≈øe of ≈øupplyes, yet they them≈øelves are in a farre wor≈øe condition, being in want of mo≈øt things nece≈ø≈øary, not onely for the maintayning of a warre, but even of life the judgement of God being remarkeable upon them in this, that as their bloudy and treacherous Religion made them inhumanely cruell in ≈øhedding the prote≈øtants bloud, ≈øo now the famine among≈øt many of them hath made them unnaturally, and Canniball-like eate and feede one upon another. Therefore that they may have time to expect from their friends abroad new ≈øupplyes both of victuals and ammunition, and may without mole≈øtation reape the fruite of this harve≈øt, they have laboured a treaty for a Ce≈ø≈øation, which project of theirs doth no le≈ø≈øe ayme at the overthrow of the remainder of the Prote≈øtants in that kingdome then their treacherous taking of Armes at the fir≈øt did intend the de≈øtruction of them all; for their Ce≈ø≈øation and ho≈øtility, their warre and peace are alike
to be e≈øteemed of, and with tho≈øe that neyther in peace nor warre keepe any faith, it is be≈øt to be in perpetuall defiance: Therefore the Lords and Commons in Parliament a≈ø≈øembled according to their continued care of that kingdome of Ireland doe in a ≈øpeciall manner take into their con≈øideration the condition thereof upon this occa≈øion of an intended Ce≈ø≈øation, and ≈øo much the rather becau≈øe it is feared that the Prote≈øtant forces through want of Provi≈øion for their Armies, may at la≈øt, if not relieved be per≈øwaded to admit of this cour≈øe in hope thereby to procure ≈øome meanes for their ≈øub≈øi≈øting, as al≈øo becau≈øe there is too much ground to ≈øu≈øpect, that if this Ce≈ø≈øation ≈øhould be agreed unto, they might have opportunitie to joyne with the papi≈øt party heere for their greater ≈øtrenghtning. And though it were to have no influence upon this kingdome, yet the evill con≈øequences of it are ≈øo many and pernicious to Ireland, that this Parliament ≈øhould betray the tru≈øt repo≈øed in them, if they did not declare again≈øt this Ce≈ø≈øation, and u≈øe all meanes in time to make it prove abortive, And therefore they de≈øire that it may be ob≈øerved and taken notice of.

Fir≈øt from whence the Coun≈øell and de≈øigne of this Ce≈ø≈øation ari≈øeth even from the rebels and Papi≈øts them≈øelves for their owne pre≈øervation, for ≈øoone after they had mi≈ø≈øed of their intent to make them≈øelves ab≈øolute ma≈øters of that kingdome of Ireland by their treacherous ≈øurpri≈øes. And ≈øeeing that this kingdome did with mo≈øt generous and Chri≈øtian re≈øolutions undertake the charges of warre for the reliefe and recovery of Ireland, propo≈øitions were brought from the Rebellion the Lords Dillon & Taffe at which time they were intercepted. „Äà‚óä„Äâ re≈øtrayned by order of the hou≈øe of Commons: After that, they had the boldne≈ø≈øe even while their hands were ≈øtill imbrued in the Prote≈øtant bloud to petition to his Maje≈øtie that their demands might be heard, and for this purpo≈øe they obtayned a Commi≈ø≈øion to be ≈øent over into Ireland to divers per≈øons of quality (whereof ≈øome were Papi≈øts) to heare, receive, & tran≈ømit to his Maje≈øty their demands which was done accordingly, and one Ma≈øter Bourke, a notorious pragmaticke Irish papist, was the chiefe ≈øollicitor in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, after this, the ju≈øt revenging God giving daily ≈øucce≈ø≈øe to the handfull of the Protestant forces, again≈øt their great numbers, ≈øo that by a wonderfull ble≈ø≈øing from heaven they were in mo≈øt parts put to
the wor≈øt. Then did they begin to ≈øet on foote an overtime for a Ce≈ø≈øation of Armes, concerning which, what going and comming hath beene between the Court and the Rebels is very well knowne, and what meetings and treaties have beene held about it in Ireland by warrant of his Maje≈øties ample Commi≈ø≈øion ≈øent to that effect; and what reception and countenance mo≈øt pragmaticke Papists negotiating the bu≈øine≈ø≈øe & found at Court, and that tho≈øe of the State in Dublin who had ≈øo much Religion, and hone≈øty as to di≈ø≈øwade the Ce≈ø≈øation were fir≈øt di≈øcountenanced and at la≈øt put out of their places, and re≈øtrayned to pri≈øon, as Sir VVilliam Par≈øons one of the Lords ≈øu≈øtices there, Sir Iohn Temple Ma≈øter of the Rolles, Sir Adam Loftus Trea≈øurer of Ireland, and Trea≈øurer at warres, and Sir Robert Meredith one al≈øo of the Councell-Table.

Secondly the Lords and Commons de≈øire it may be ob≈øerved that during all the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages and negotiations the hou≈øes of Parliament were never acquainted by the ≈øtate of Ireland with the treaty of a Ce≈ø≈øation, much le≈ø≈øe was their advi≈øe or Coun≈øell demanded, notwith≈øtanding that the care, and managing of the war was devolved on them both by Act of Parliament, and by his Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øion under the great Seale, to advi≈øe, order, and di≈øpo≈øe of all things concerning the government, and defence of that kingdome, but the wants of the Army were often repre≈øented and complayned of, whereby with much craft a ground was preparing for the pretext, wherewith now they would cover the Coun≈øell of this Ce≈ø≈øation, as if nothing had drawne it on, but the extreame wants of their Armies, whereas it is evident, that the report of ≈øuch a treaty have beene (in a great part) the cau≈øe of their wants, for thereby the adventurers were di≈øheartned, contributions were ≈øtopped, and by the admittance to Court of the negotiators of this Ce≈ø≈øation: their wicked Councell have had that influence, as to procure the intercepting of much provi≈øions which were ≈øent for Ireland, ≈øo that Ships going for Ireland with victuals, and others comming from thence with commodities to exchange for victuals, have beene taken by Dunkerkers having his Maje≈øties warrant, but al≈øo by English Ships commanded by Sir Iohn Pennigton under his Maje≈øty. And moreover the Parliament me≈ø≈øengers ≈øent into ≈øeverall Counties with the Ordinance of Ianuary la≈øt for Ioanes, and contributions, have beene taken,
and impri≈øoned, their Money taken from them, and not one penny eyther loane or contribution hath been ≈øuffered to be ≈øent in for Ireland, from tho≈øe Counties which were under the power of the Kings army, while in the meane time the hou≈øes of Parliament by their ordinances, declarations, & ≈øollicitations to the City of London, & the counties free from the terror of the Kings forces were ≈øtill procuring not contemptible ayde and reliefe for the di≈øtre≈ø≈øes of Ireland,

Thirdly, as the Lords and Commons have rea≈øon to declare again≈øt this plot & de≈øigne of a Ce≈ø≈øation of armes, as being treated and carryed on without their advi≈øe, ≈øo al≈øo, becau≈øe of the great prejudice which will thereby redound to the Prote≈øtant Religion and the encouragement, and advancement which it will give to the practi≈øe of Popery, when the≈øe rebellious Papi≈øts, ≈øhall by this agreement continue and ≈øet up with more freedome their Idolatrous wor≈øhip, their Popish ≈øuper≈øtitions, and Romish abominations in all the places of their command, to the di≈øhonoring of God, the grieving of all true Protestant hearts, the di≈øpi≈øing the Lawes of the Crown of England, and to the provoking of the wrath of a Iealous God, as if both kingdomes had not ≈ømarted enough already for this ≈øin, of too much connyving at, and tolerating of Antichri≈øtian Idolatry, under pretext of Civill contracts and politick agreements.

In the fourth place they de≈øire it may be ob≈øerved that this Ce≈ø≈øation will prove di≈øhonorable to the publicke faith of this kingdome, it will elude and make null the acts and ordinances of Parliament made for the forfeyting of Rebels Lands, at the pa≈ø≈øing of which acts it was repre≈øented that ≈øuch a cour≈øe would drive the Rebels to de≈øpayre, & it prove ≈øo, but otherwi≈øe then was meant. For di≈øpayring of their force and courage they go about to overcome us with their craft.

La≈øtly what ≈øhall become of the many poore exiled Protestants turned out of their e≈øtates by this rebellion, who mu≈øt now continue begging their bread, while the rebels ≈øhall enjoy their lands and hou≈øes, And who ≈øhall ≈øecure the re≈øt of the Prote≈øtants that eyther by their owne courage, indu≈øtry, & great charges hath kept their po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, or by the ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of our Armies have beene re≈øtored, can there be any a≈ø≈øurance gotten from a perfidious enemy
of a Ce≈ø≈øation, from butchery, and breach of agreement, when they ≈øhall ≈øee a fit time and opportunity.

The≈øe and many other con≈øiderations being well weighed, it will appeare evidently, that this de≈øigne of a Ce≈ø≈øation is a deepe plot laid by the Rebells, and really invented for their own ≈øafety and fal≈øely pretended to bee for the benefit of our Armies: And whereas the Lords and Commons have no certaine information, that the treaty is concluded, but are informed by ≈øeverall letters, that all the Protestants as well inhabitants as ≈øoldiors in that kingdome, are re≈øolved to with≈øtand that proceeding, and to adventure on the greate≈øt extremities, rather then have any ≈øort of peace with that generation, who have ≈øo cruelly, in time of peace, murthered many thou≈øands of our Countrey-men, and laboured to extirpe the Protestant Religion from among≈øt them, ≈øo they doe believe, that the≈øe rumors of a Ce≈ø≈øation were fir≈øt contrived by the enemies of our Religion and peace, and by their practi≈øes the treaty was carried on with much ≈øubtility and ≈øollicitation thereby to ≈øtoppe the ≈øending of ≈øupplies from thence to our Armies, and for the cooling of the affections of tho≈øe who have already ≈øhewed their zeale to the weale of Ireland, and therefore the onely meanes to defeate this their policy, and prevent the evills intended by it, is to ≈øettle a cour≈øe whereby the army of Ireland may be at lea≈øt fenced again≈øt hunger and cold, for which purpo≈øe it is de≈øired, that all tho≈øe who are well affected to the Prote≈øtant Reliligion, either in that or this kingdome. And all tho≈øe who by their adventures already made, have imbarked their particular intere≈øts with the publicke of that kingdome, and doe de≈øire a good returne of their engagements will joyne their endeavours for obviating of that nece≈ø≈øity, which may be made a ≈øtrong argument to enforce a de≈øtructive Ce≈ø≈øation of Armes, & that they would nor through too much ≈øu≈øpition and jealou≈øie of it forbeare the providing of ≈øupplies, and ≈øo occa≈øion that inconvenience which they ought by all meanes to prevent, for by ≈øo doeing they will loo≈øe all their former paines and charges, and the withholding of provi≈øions will gaine credit to that calumny laid again≈øt this kingdome, and neglecting the armies of Ireland, and by the continuing of ≈øupplies, the≈øe forces will bee encouraged to continue the warre, and ≈øo ‚Ä¢ owne both their worke and ours.

And la≈øtly the Rebels ≈øeeing a≈ø≈øi≈øtance again≈øt them ≈øtill flowing from hence mu≈øt needs be out of hope of pro≈øecuting or concluding this their de≈øigne, the cry of much Prote≈øtant bloud, the great indigencie of many ruynate families, the danger of our Religion almo≈øt exiled out of that kingdome calls for this la≈øt act of piety, charity, ju≈øtice, and policy from us, which being re≈øolved on letters are to bee di≈øpatcht to the ≈øeverall partes of that kingdome to encourage the Commanders and ≈øouldiers upon the fore≈øaid rea≈øons and a≈ø≈øurances, that they may not hearken to ≈øuch an unju≈øt and deceitfull coun≈øell, and as by their pro≈øecuting of the warre through Gods ble≈ø≈øing, they have ≈øucce≈ø≈øe fully re≈øi≈øted the Rebels cruelty, ≈øo they may upon this occa≈øion beware they be not over reached by their crafts.

All which the Lords and Commons doe earne≈øtly de≈øire may be ≈øeriou≈øly taken into heart by all the kingdome, and that from tho≈øe other encouragements mentioned at large, in the ordinance of the fourteenth of Iuly la≈øt, and ≈øuch as are now offered, a cour≈øe may be taken wherby ≈øuch a con≈øtant weekely contribution may be ≈øetled, as will ≈øupply the Army in Ireland, The meere nece≈ø≈øity of nature which may be more punctually and ≈øea≈øonably tran≈ømitted into the ≈øeverall parts of that kingdome according to their re≈øpective wants, that ≈øo the benefit and honour of ≈øo pious a worke, happily begun, and ≈øucce≈ø≈øively hitherto carryed on may not be lo≈øt when ≈øo little remaynes to be done, And that the ≈øaving of a kingdome, the ree≈øtabli≈øhing of ≈øo many Prote≈øtants Churches, the repo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing of ≈øo many thou≈øand Chri≈øtians unto their e≈øtates may not be de≈øerted and let fall to the ground for a little more paines and co≈øt.
